hints_html:
Recall that the average value of a continuous random variable X with values between a and b and probability density function p(X=x) = p(x) is defined as

\[\begin{aligned} \int_a^b xp(x)\,dx\end{aligned}\]

How can you relate the given cumulative function F(t) to the probability density function p(t)?

For a quick solution: The given cumulative function is the typical cumulative function of a waiting time. The expected waiting time is already hidden in the exponential function.
hints_latex:
How can you relate the given cumulative function \emph{F(t)} to the
probability density function \emph{p(t)}?

For a quick solution: The given cumulative function is the typical
cumulative function of a \emph{waiting time}. The expected waiting time
is already hidden in the exponential function.
hints_raw:
Recall that the average value of a continuous random variable ''X'' with values between ''a'' and ''b'' and probability density function ''p(X=x) = p(x)'' is defined as

:<math> \int_a^b xp(x)\,dx </math>
How can you relate the given cumulative function ''F(t)'' to the probability density function ''p(t)''?
For a quick solution: The given cumulative function is the typical cumulative function of a ''waiting time''. The expected waiting time is already hidden in the exponential function.
question: 7 (a)
sols_html:
To get from the cumulative function to the probability density function, you need to take the derivate, i.e.

\[\begin{aligned} p(t) = F'(t) = \frac1{12}e^{-t/12}.\end{aligned}\]

Now we apply the definition of the expected value to the random variable X that denotes the waiting time:

\[\begin{aligned} \overline{X} = \int_0^\infty tp(t)\,dt.\end{aligned}\]

This is an improper integral, so we treat it with caution. To solve it, we apply integration by parts with u=t and dv = e-t/12dt and obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \overline{X} &= \int_0^\infty tp(t)\,dt \\ &= \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} \left(\frac1{12} \int_0^T te^{-t/12}\,dt\right) \\ &= \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} \left(\left.\frac1{12} t(-12e^{-t/12})\right|_0^T + \frac1{12} \int_0^T 12e^{-t/12}\,dt\right) \\ &= \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} \left(-Te^{-T/12} + 0 - \left.12e^{-t/12}\right|_0^T\right) \\ &= \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} \left(-12e^{-T/12} + 12e^0\right) \\ &= 12;\end{aligned}\]

From class and the course notes you may remember that waiting time typically has a probability density function and cumulative function of the form

\[\begin{aligned} p(t) = ke^{-kt}, \quad \text{and} \quad F(t) = 1-e^{-kt},\end{aligned}\]

respectively. In this case, the expected waiting time is given by 1/k. Here k = 1/12 so that the expected value is 12.
sols_latex:
From class and the course notes you may remember that waiting time
typically has a probability density function and cumulative function of
the form

\begin{align*}
p(t) = ke^{-kt}, \quad \text{and} \quad F(t) = 1-e^{-kt},
\end{align*}

respectively. In this case, the expected waiting time is given by
\emph{1/k}. Here \emph{k = 1/12} so that the expected value is
\emph{12}.
sols_raw:
To get from the cumulative function to the probability density function, you need to take the derivate, i.e.

:<math> p(t) = F'(t) = \frac1{12}e^{-t/12}. </math>

Now we apply the definition of the expected value to the random variable ''X'' that denotes the waiting time:

:<math> \overline{X} = \int_0^\infty tp(t)\,dt. </math>

This is an improper integral, so we treat it with caution. To solve it, we apply integration by parts with ''u=t'' and ''dv = e<sup>-t/12</sup>dt'' and obtain

:<math> \begin{align} \overline{X} &= \int_0^\infty tp(t)\,dt \\
&= \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} \left(\frac1{12} \int_0^T te^{-t/12}\,dt\right) \\
&= \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} \left(\left.\frac1{12} t(-12e^{-t/12})\right|_0^T + \frac1{12} \int_0^T 12e^{-t/12}\,dt\right) \\
&= \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} \left(-Te^{-T/12} + 0 - \left.12e^{-t/12}\right|_0^T\right) \\
&= \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} \left(-12e^{-T/12} + 12e^0\right) \\
&= 12;
\end{align}
</math>
From class and the course notes you may remember that waiting time typically has a probability density function and cumulative function of the form

:<math> p(t) = ke^{-kt}, \quad \text{and} \quad F(t) = 1-e^{-kt}, </math>

respectively. In this case, the expected waiting time is given by ''1/k''. Here ''k = 1/12'' so that the expected value is ''12''.
statement_html:
The probability that a newly divided cell will divide again before t hours (where t \(\geq\) 0) is given by

\[\begin{aligned} F(t) = 1-e^{-t/12}\end{aligned}\]

(a) If you start observing a cell immediately after a division, how long, on average, would you have to wait to see the next division?
statement_raw:
The probability that a newly divided cell will divide again '''before''' ''t'' hours (where ''t'' ≥ 0) is given by
:<math> F(t) = 1-e^{-t/12}</math>

(a) If you start observing a cell immediately after a division, how long, on average, would you have to wait to see the next division?
